text:
How not to get diphtheria and what to do if it happens
01 Nov 2019, 13:00 by Ekaterina Komissarova
In 5-10% of cases, it is already impossible to save the sick person. There is only one way to reduce risks.
What is diphtheria and why is it dangerous?
Diphtheria * is a bacterial infection that usually affects the mucous membranes of the throat and nose. Its causative agent, the bacterium Corynebacterium diphtheriae, also known as diphtheria bacillus, secretes the most dangerous toxin that can destroy body tissues. * Source: Diphtheria
Localized in the throat and nose, the infection kills the cells that it hits. Diphtheria creates a dense gray film (pseudomembrane) * on the surface of tissues, consisting of dead cells, microbes, and other substances. Over time, this film grows and, if not combated, can completely block the airways. With predictable death. * Source: Diphtheria. Symptoms
Just 100 years ago, diphtheria was * the main cause of death among children under five years old. * Source: Diphtheria. Clinicians
But that's not all. The toxin can enter the bloodstream and with its help spread throughout the body. For example, attack the heart muscle, causing inflammation (myocarditis) and disturbances in the heart. Or damage the nerves, causing muscle weakness, difficulty swallowing, and even stop breathing.
Today, diphtheria mortality even with timely treatment reaches * 5‚Äì10% among adults and 20% among children. * Source: Diphtheria
What are the symptoms of diphtheria
The severity of the disease directly depends on how much the toxin has spread throughout the body. Therefore, it is extremely important to recognize diphtheria and begin treatment as early as possible.
True, there is a difficulty: at the initial stage, the disease is similar to a common cold. This is a serious reason not to disregard even a simple SARS. And even more so, consult a therapist or ENT specialist if you notice characteristic symptoms. Here they are:

sharp weakness;
temperature rise;
a sore throat;
enlargement of the cervical lymph nodes;
swelling of the soft tissues of the neck;
hoarseness, hoarseness of voice;
discharge from the nose;
difficulty or rapid breathing;
the most significant sign is a gray film covering the tonsils and partly the palate.

Also, you simply must visit a therapist if you have contacted a person who had diphtheria established a few days after the meeting. Do not hesitate, especially if you have not been vaccinated against this disease or more than 10 years have passed since the last vaccination.
However, even if you are sure that there was no contact with the patient, the appearance of a gray film on the throat is a clear indication for an immediate visit to the doctor. The fact is that some people can be carriers of diphtheria, but not get sick at the same time. There is a risk that one of the hidden carriers met on your way.
How to treat diphtheria
Only a professional doctor can make a diagnosis. You may be asked to have a smear smear test to check for diphtheria bacillus. But if the doctor suspects diphtheria, treatment begins as quickly as possible - even before the results of a laboratory test are obtained.
They get rid of diphtheria exclusively in an inpatient hospital. Treatment * includes: * Source: Diphtheria. Diagnosis and Treatment

The introduction of anti-diphtheria serum. It contains an antitoxin that protects the body from the poison secreted by diphtheria bacillus.
The use of antibiotics. Their task is to destroy pathogenic bacteria.

Attention! Diphtheria serum has a number of serious side effects *, so you can enter it only according to the indications and under the supervision of a doctor. In addition, antitoxin is not always necessary. Diphtheria also has non-toxigenic strains: this means that bacteria do not secrete poison, which can destroy body cells. In this case, the serum is even harmful. However, only an infectious disease doctor can decide whether or not to administer an antitoxin. * Source: Diphtheria Antitoxin. Side effects
And once again, recall. Even treatment started on time does not guarantee recovery. The best way to avoid complications up to a fatal outcome is to prevent diphtheria from attacking the body at all.
How not to get diphtheria
Diphtheria is distributed mainly in three ways:

Airborne. You can get your dose of bacteria if someone sneezes at you or you just talked face to face with an infected person.
Through personal items. For example, you can become infected by taking a sip of water from a glass from which the carrier previously drank.
Through contaminated public objects. The bacterium may exist for some time on handrails in public transport, door handles or, for example, toys in the children's room of a large supermarket.

Given all this, hygiene is crucial. Try to be as small as possible in public places with a large number of visitors, do not use other people's cutlery, wash your hands more often and get rid of the habit of touching your mouth or nose with dirty fingers.
However, hygiene alone will not protect you from infection.
The most reliable way to reduce risks is to get a diphtheria vaccine.
According to * the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 99% of vaccinated people are reliably protected from a deadly infection. * Source: CDC statistics demonstrate dramatic declines in vaccine ‚Äë preventable diseases when compared with the pre ‚Äë vaccine era
This, by the way, does not mean that vaccinees do not get sick. It's just that their organisms are ready to face the bacterium and can successfully resist it. A vaccinated person, picking up a diphtheria bacillus, is likely to get sick easily - perhaps without even realizing that it was diphtheria, and not a cold. But his unvaccinated neighbor, the same "cold" can kill.
Whether anti-vaccination is worth the risk is up to you.
